#Text=Prune Hostas
#Text=Hostas are a popular garden plant that are prized for their lush foliage .

#Text=They ’re typically easy to care for , but they do benefit from being cut back when they go into dormancy each fall , and you may need to prune them if you ’re dealing with garden pests like slugs .
#Text=You may also want to snip off your hosta flowers once they start to fade to enhance the beauty of the foliage .
#Text=Luckily , pruning a hosta is easy to do !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Deadheading the Hostas
#Text=Use sharp shears to cut the flower stalks near the base .
#Text=The point of removing the flower stem is to keep it from detracting from the look of your garden , so you want to shear it as close to the plant 's base as possible .
#Text=This way , the broad leaves of the hosta will hide the snipped-off stalk .
#Text=Snip off hosta flowers before they mature to emphasize the foliage .
#Text=If you chose a hosta plant because you love the ornamental leaves , but you 're not crazy about the flowers , you can snip them off before they mature and go to seed .
#Text=However , if you prefer , you can leave the flowers on until they wilt .
#Text=Once the flowers go to seed , they absorb energy that would otherwise be used on developing the leaves .
#Text=If you remove the flowers on a hosta , it usually will not flower again that season .
#Text=Cut off the blooms once they turn brown if you prefer to keep the hosta flowers .
#Text=Although the leggy stems of hosta flowers can seem unsightly once the flower is wilted , you 'll get more enjoyment out of the bloom by leaving it on the plant than you would by cutting it .
#Text=Hosta flowers are delicate and they wilt quickly once cut .
#Text=Bees and hummingbirds often favor hosta flowers , so leaving the flowers in place can help benefit your local ecosystem .
#Text=Do n't remove the flowers if you want to attract birds to your garden .
#Text=The seed-heads on hosta flowers are often eaten by birds .
#Text=If you like the idea of keeping the local wildlife healthy , you may want to let the flowers go to seed .
#Text=If you do this , all you 'll need to do is cut the plant back in the fall .
#Text=The flower stalks will turn brown when the leaves do .
#Text=Cutting Back Your Hostas
#Text=Prune your hostas after the first frost .
#Text=You do n't have to cut back hostas for the health of the plant , but they do look unattractive through winter .
#Text=The plant will turn brown and wilt after the first hard freeze , so it 's best to prune it then .
#Text=Hostas are one of the earliest plant in the garden to die back , but they do return in the spring .
#Text=In addition to being unattractive , the leaves are often home to slug eggs , and leaving the foliage will allow the eggs to hatch .
#Text=Slugs are a big problem for hosta gardeners , and they can destroy an entire , otherwise healthy plant .
#Text=Cut the plant down with pruning shears to .
#Text=Everything your hosta needs to survive the winter is buried underground , so no harm will come to the plant if you cut it back to ground level .
#Text=However , leaving a few inches when you cut will help you mark the location of the plant .
#Text=Hostas winter better in the ground than they do in containers , so there ’s no need to dig them up for the winter .
#Text=Since the hosta will be dead when you start pruning , it should be easy to snip off the body of the plant .
#Text=Lay down a layer of mulch to insulate your hosta plant .
#Text=If you do n't mulch your hosta during the growing season , you may want to do so after you prune it .
#Text=Although hosta is tolerant of the cold , a layer of mulch can help protect it from repeated freezing and then thawing , which can affect the hosta 's dormancy cycle .
#Text=Once the weather starts to warm up , remove some of the excess mulch from around the hosta 's crown to prevent it from rotting .
#Text=Pruning to Treat Pests and Diseases
#Text=Remove leaves which have been eaten by slugs , rabbits , or other garden pests .
#Text=Hostas are a popular snack for a number of insects and animals .
#Text=If you notice that your hosta has been nibbled on , use a small pair of shears or a sharp knife to snip away the damaged leaves as close to the base of the stem as possible .
#Text=Hail can also damage the leaves of your hosta plant .
#Text=Removing the damaged leaves will encourage the hosta to direct its energy towards the healthy parts of the plant .
#Text=Cut away infected leaves and stems .
#Text=When you ’re watering your hosta plant , try to direct the flow of water down towards the base of the plant .
#Text=Otherwise , you may start to see wilting leaves , black dots , or stunted growth , which could be signs of a fungus or nematode .
#Text=If you see these signs , promptly cut away the infected leaves or stems from the plant .
#Text=Sanitize your cutting tools after pruning infected plants .
#Text=If one of your plants is infected with a fungus , virus , or other diseases , you may spread the blight with your tools as you ’re pruning .
#Text=Even if you do n’t see any signs of illness , wipe down the blades of your tool with rubbing alcohol before you move to the next plant .
#Text=If you ’re removing plants infected with hosta virus X , or HVX , wash your tools and your hands after you finish handling each individual plant .
#Text=Burn infected hosta plants if you can .
#Text=There are a number of diseases which can affect your hostas , the most serious of which is HVX .

#Text=If you notice light or dark green lines travelling along the veins of your hosta leaves , mottled or blotchy discoloration on the leaves , circular spots , or wilting leaves , it could be a sign of the rapidly-spreading hosta virus X. Remove the entire plant to keep it from spreading .
#Text=Burning is the most effective way to destroy HVX , though you 'll need to make sure it ’s allowed in your area .
#Text=Other diseases which might affect your plant include foliar and root-knot nematodes , petiole rot , Southern blight , and the anthracnose fungus .
#Text=If you can not burn the infected hosta plants , send them to the landfill .
#Text=Do not add HVX-infected hostas to your compost pile , otherwise you may spread the disease .
#Text=Quick Summary
